Posts.Content: On 7/9/2008 tomslady wrote: I have recently been dx with invasive ductal carcinoma of the left breast. Had the lumpectomy and setinal lobe disection last week and now have to wait until next week and meet with the oncologist to find out what the next step is going to be. My husband has been very supportive through all this but i feel guilty putting him through this. We have been married just over a year and now all this. I don't know that I want to go any farther with treament. I have been cut open 4 times in the last 6 weeks and I am feeling very sick when i look at my scares, I know they are new and they will fade but right now I cannot even look at myself in the mirror without wanting to scream.  Intamacy has become a thing if the oast since all this has started and I think that is the hardest part of all this, I need to feel close to my husband, i need hito touch me and love me the way he used to before I got sick. How so I relay this to him without pushing him. It is going to happen sooner then later that I will not physically be able to love him and feel close to him but now while I can he is scared. Does anyone have any advice for me or encouraging words of wisdom. I need something to hold on to right now.  Thanks for listening. Hi again - I just replied to you on another message, but I will add a couple of things here.  First, I'm sure you husband is not scared of you but scared for you.  If you've told him to let you go, that you don't want to go any farther with treatment, I'm sure he is scared to death he is going to lose you.  Have you told him how you feel?  If your doctor has given you an all clear for intimacy - then tell your husband what you need.  This is the love of your life - your best friend - talk to him (and I know at your age that can sometimes be easier said than done).  You have no reason to feel guilty - this is not anything that you did wrong.  Discovering you have cancer did not make your husband stop loving you or make him love you any less.  I would venture to say that it probably has more to do with being afraid he will hurt you.  You may go through a period that intimacy will be out of the question but it will only be for a short time - it is not permanent.  Open communication is very important right now - trust your husband - tell him exactly what you have told us.  My money is on him coming through for you.  Diana
Posts.Title: not sure if I can fight this battle

Posts.Content: On 7/17/2008 tomslady wrote: Ok heres the skinny! I have gone back to work for now as my surgeon called last Friday and was very exited about my insurance paying at least part of that Oncotype DX test I was telling you all about earlier.  Results should be back in about 2 weeks the tumor was sent off this week to the lab.  I have an apt with the cbc docs on 8/1 and with the radiation team on the 5th, so still not knowing what my tx regiman is going to be still alittle on edge. Finding myself falling slightly into a depressed state I am trying to stop it before it gets worse, upped the dosage on my antidepressant for the time being.  Hubby still holding strong and my mom and my sister where out for a visit this week. My mom was glad to see I looked so good not that she is bias or anything but I think actually seeing me has put her mind at ease alittle.  She left me with encouraging words and told me if I need her to come out again once tx starts she will be there in a flash. I have a good support team I think.  As I said I have gone back to work for now but only working 6-7 hours a day and very tired when I get home, my breast is swelling again, called the surgeon she said it is to be expected and not to worry but if it is not better next to call and she will see me just to be sure.  My incisions are healing (slowly) but they do look better.Bruising is still present but healing time is very slow she tells me.  My rigth breast is still lack and blue from the biopsy done like 4 weeks ago, bruising from iv's still very pronounced as well.  I guess I will close for now. Love to all and God Bless Kristine Hi Kristine You sound much better which is wonderful to hear.  Sweetie, you have been through a lot and you will have days of feeling depressed but you have so much to fight for.  You have a wonderful husband, your children, and a dynamite mom (many don't have any support).  As for your mom, if you need her, please don't hesitate to call her.  As a mom of five grown children, I know I want to be there for them when they are hurting.  Imagine you are now preparing for a 10K run - you can't look behind you because you will falter and you can't look to the side because you will lose your focus, you look straight ahead keeping your eyes on the finish line.  As any runner will atest to, the "run" itself is only a short period out of the rest of your life.  Once you cross that finish line, like all runners, you will need to rest but after a recuperation period, you will have the rest of a very long life to enjoy your new husband and your children - and one day your grandchildren (I know - I know that is a way in the future but trust me, grandchildren are something special to look forward to - all the fun with none of the work).  You will make it through this and I believe w/ an even deeper appreciation of your wonderful husband, your entire family, and even your friends.  Take care of yourself and keep us posted as to how you are doing.  I speak for all of your pen pals on here that we all care about you as well.    Diana
Posts.Title: waiting on test results

Posts.Content: Hi Dovie My journey with cancer has been short compared to yours and I had a different type of cancer (oralpharyngeal) so I'm not in a position to give you any advice on treatment; however, I did receive my treatment at Cancer Treatment Center in Zion and highly recommend them (I know they have a total of 5 hospitals).  If nothing else, I would suggest going there for a second opinion.    The gentleman who started CTCA did so after losing his own mother to cancer and felt that there was a lack of communication and care involving his mother.  He believes that the patient's care & comfort as well as the caregivers comfort are the most important things.  They have a motto that God didn't give us an expiration date so they will not either.  Everyone - the doctors, the nurses, the technicians - and others were amazing.  Many (doctors included) are cancer survivors so they've been there - done that.  I had a nurse laughingly tell me how she taunted her sister about having a prettier shaped head than her - after she (the nurse) had lost all of her hair from having chemo for breast cancer.  They really do know what you are going through and were a God send during one of the most difficult times of my life.     What was especially important to me was that CTCA believes in an integrative cancer treatment approach.  They combine conventional methods, such as surgery, radiation, chemo, and immunotherapy with complementary therapies such as nutrition, naturopathic med, mind-body med, physical therapy, pain management, and spiritual support - you can participate in one, two, all, or none of the complementary treatments (I even tried acupuncture for nausea).  They even had sessions on comedy as laughter does help.      I know they pay for flights in for the patient - I'm not sure about a caregiver but they may.  I knew several people that flew in for treatment (and still are flying in) but we drove and they paid us mileage.  They even have stretch limos that pick you  up at the airport.  They are not flaunting anything - but who better deserves to be pampered if not someone battling cancer?  They have contracts w/ all the local hotels and you are given a very reasonable rate (they pay a portion and you pay a portion).  Shuttles transport you back and forth to CTCA - no charge.  One really nice thing they do is handle everything for you - flight arrangements, limo pick up, hotel reservations, and filing all insurance.  At a time we have so much on our mind, it is wonderful to leave all the details to them and let us concentrate on getting through treatment.  I received excellent care from CTCA and know that they had my best interests at heart.  You know how they say little things mean a lot - well for me it was the receptionist in the radiation department remembering me by name and asking how I was each and every day.  I also feel as if they are on top of all research going on.  My medical oncologist at CTCA stopped giving me heparin a couple of months into treatment because research now shows it doesn't help.  About 4 months after they stopped my heparin intake I was hospitalized at a local hospital (where I was originally diagnosed).  They gave me daily heparin shots in the stomach even though I tried to object.  For me it was saying CTCA was ahead of our local hospital as to the latest research data.  If you have any questions about CTCA please ask, I will be happy to answer them.  I wish you the best in your days ahead and will add you into my prayers. Diana
Posts.Title: Chemo not working, anyone experience this?

Posts.Content: On 7/29/2008 Dovie wrote: Diana, Thank you so much for your input on CTCA. I am traveling to Tulsa, OK tomorrow for evaluation over the following 3-5 days. I am looking forward to seeing what it is all about. I did confirm that my suspicion that the chemo I was on was not working so I am currently in no treatment. I am scared and feel a little lost. There is so much to think about and the pressure of making the right decision is really tough. But, I have faith that something will turn up. Thanks again for sharing your experience with CTCA! Hi Dovie I read where you are seeing another doctor next Tues also.  That is good because when making such an important decision I don't think it ever hurts to get 2nd and 3rd opinions.  It is so important that you are comfortable with your doctors and your treatment when dealing with cancer.  I go to CTCA in Zion on Thur and Fri for my check up and hoping for a clear scan and good results on my blood work.  My prayers are with you and just imagine a hug coming to you Thur from CTCA in Zion.  Even if you decide on one of the trials at the other cancer center, I think you will like CTCA.  For me, they were like family that were with me throughout.  Please let me know what you decide to do - I know how difficult it can be in trying to make the right decision for treatment.    Diana
Posts.Title: Chemo not working, anyone experience this?

Posts.Content: On 8/14/2008 mrsscott wrote:   On 8/14/2008 BarbInTexas wrote: I'd talk to your radiologist about the possibility of damage to the hair cells in the ears causing her hearing loss. Mine were damaged by chemo and it is, unfortunately, permanent.  About 40% gone now. Seems like if her ears were peeling inside and out, that it was rad. burns and they should level with you as to the chance of hearing loss from that. Ask. Sometimes just knowing the REASON for something makes it easier to bear and certainly easier to explain to others. But some side-effects are only temporary and it would be nice to know that, too. Hope this helps~ Barb    Thanks so much for your response.  Her hearing has improved some with time.  Unfortunately, she has been battling a bad case of pneumonia and can't take her chemo.  I'll make sure they ask.  Thanks again, Wynette Hi Wynette I had radiation and chemo for cancer of the left tonsil.  As a result I have a substantial hearing loss and I knew ahead of time that if any hair cells were destroyed that it was permanent.  When I mentioned the hearing loss to my oncologist he wasn't surprised.  I'm glad her hearing has improved.   Diana
Posts.Title: Hearing Loss

Posts.Content: On Oct 29, 2011 5:45 AM passionfish wrote: Thanks for the reply...I have not had a mammo as of yet..having no insurance makes it very complicated..  I feel a little guilty about my post...So many women suffering and I post an inane message..I took a huge risk by not having the bilateral masectomy and hopefully it isn`t backfiring on me.. Cheers, Passionfish :)I agree that you have no reason to feel guilty. You believed you made the best decision years ago and it would only prove otherwise if a problem arises. Cancer Compass was created to answer questions from our own experiences AND to support those with questions so what better place to post! The American Cancer Society is an excellent place to call. You might also call local hospitals to see if any free screenings are being offered in your area OR at least affordable Mamograms. I wish you well and remember everyone on CC in my daily prayers. God does hear and He does answer! Diana
Posts.Title: DCIS & LCIS ??

Posts.Content: On 8/19/2008 Arnold wrote: My 75 year old sister appears to be in her last days, if not hours, in her one year fight with recurrent breast cancer.  She is in the hospital that she retired from 10 years ago.  She worked in all of the units including a stint in surgery.  Her longest was in geriatrics where she served as head nurse for many years.  We are all God's special children but she is one of those special souls that is loved and respected by all.  Always cheerfull and smiling and has been my role model in my fight with colon cancer.  I have never heard her gossip or say a bad word about anybody.  We always hold out for a miracle and pray to God that she will survive.  But, the reality is that she will be in God's loving hands shortly  She has never complained or given up hope.  She is a fighter.. My other sister went to visit her today and said she is under heavy sedation and is being kept as comfortable as possible.  She touched her cheek, told her she loved her and is sitting in vigil for all of us in the family.  This is the third in our immediate family to be taken by this horrible disease.  My Father by lung cancer and my mother by brain cancer.  God Bless and Good Luck to you all. Arnold - My thoughts and prayers go out to you and your family.  I am so sorry that you are losing someone you love but I'm sure God holds a special place in Heaven for her.  As you described your sister - never gossiping or saying a bad word about anyone - I thought of my mother who was so like your sister.  A gentle caring woman.  Warm memories abound as I sit here remembering times we shared.  Isn't God wonderful to provide us with memories to fill the loneliness after He takes our loved one home.  Take care and please offer my condolences to your other sister also.  Diana
Posts.Title: My Wonderfull Sister

Posts.Content: On 7/12/2008 smitten wrote: Hi, y'all. I'd love to say it's nice being here, but...... 53 years old, married, two children, one still at home.  I'm a RN and found a lump in my left upper chest wall at work one day in late February.  Asked one of the docs to check it out and he sent me to a surgeon who specializes in breast cancer.  Biopsied the spot, and low and behold it was invasive ductal breast cancer.  Then began my journey to the land of oncologists, radiologists, plastic docs, etc.  We elected to do bilateral mastectomies and the first surgery date was March 18th.  All ready to go to surgery when a critical lab was reported:  blood glucose was 517 :( Surgery was rescheduled for March 28th..spent one night in Observation, discovered a hematoma and had to have surgery again the 31st.  So far I still have the tissue expanders (I call them my hockey pucks) in place.  Implant surgery is scheduled July 30th.  Had the Oncotype DX testing and scored a 43...sigh. I got my Bard PowerPort yesterday.  I see the oncologist next week to discuss type of chemo, schedules, etc.  I also see a gyno doc for the lovely and exciting transvaginal ultrasound as I'm having a complete hysterectomy (prophalactic) and my doc doesn't want to go in blindly.  Honestly, I think the thought of losing my hair is my biggest worry.  I've decided to shave it and get a spray on tan..hehe And I'm seriously considering foregoing the nipple tattooing and get a hummingbird on one breast and a flower on the other.  I've never had tattoos and love the thought of being a secret rebel ;) I've had great family/friend support, but it's great to have a place like this with people that KNOW what I'm going thru.  Thanks, y'all :-) Welcome to the club!  Talk about a vacation from you know where.  This is one vacation spot I don't ever want to return to.  You've got a wonderful outlook which really helps get you through it all.  Some have said on this site that they felt alone when tx ended - like being released to fend for themselves but NOT me.  I loved all the doctors, nurses, techs, etc. (and I received excellent care) but I sure was elated the day I began to see them every 3 mo rather than every day - 2x a day for many of them.  Keep in touch and let us know how you are doing. Diana
Posts.Title: Newbie here.....

Posts.Content: On Oct 27, 2011 11:39 AM Bahamasgirl wrote: I'm scheduled to have a sentinel node biopsy and lumpectomy tomorrow morning. I'm quite nervous, not sure what to expect. I'm not supposed to have anything to eat or drink after midnight. I don't know how I'll sleep tonight. And the doc already has warned me that inserting the dye for the biopsy, done an hour or so prior to surgery, will sting. Those who've been through this, advice please! Today's going to be a long day. How can I stay calm and get rest before tomorrow?I was claustrophobic and going into the TOMO machine (better known as the cement mixer) was beyond stressful! My oncologist prescribed Ativan prior to each radiation treatment to relax me and it worked wonders - made it all possible. What worked better than anything was recalling "Footprints" where God promises to always be with us. When questioned as to why there was only one set of footprints at the most trying times in life, God answered that is when He was carrying us. I will remember you in prayer throughout today - asking God to be with you today - to give you comfort AND to be with you tomorrow and the days ahead. Diana

Posts.Content: We begin to take the old saying "hurry up and wait!" to heart while awaiting test results. I will remember you in prayer for the best possible results! Diana

Posts.Content: I was told specifically not to use the gel you buy in a tube/bottle at the pharmacy so I asked about gel from an aloe plant and was told that could be used.  I did use it with success.  Also the Biafine later on.
Posts.Title: radiation burn

Posts.Content: On 8/13/2008 Jodie wrote:   On 8/13/2008 trehouse60 wrote: Hi Jodie, You know how it is when you're trying to think of something and can't bring it to mind - if you just let go of it and think of something else, the thing that was eluding you will just all of a sudden pop into your head? I've been trying to sleep for quite a while - just too much stuff spinning around in my head - keeping me awake.  Not cancer compass stuff - just other stuff.  All of a sudden, it pops into my head:  be a clown. I have a friend  - I'll call him Ed - who volunteers as a clown. He used to work the rodeos, as a professional clown to protect the bull riders, until he was injured and could no longer do it. Took the joy out of his life.  Then his mom passed away - that really took the joy out of his life.  Knowing that Ed was having a hard time, a friend of his that often volunteered with a group of clown for kids in the hospital asked Ed to fill in for him for just one day while the friend was out of town.  There actually were other people who could have done this, but the friend knew Ed needed the joy and laughter of children to replace the grief in his heart.   Ed wasn't real enthusiatic about filling in, but he owed the guy a favor and agreed to do it. Turns out Ed's friend was a pretty smart man.  Ed went to the hospital, worked with the kids, made them laugh, and lo and behold, they made HIM laugh. Showed him that there was still room in his heart for love and joy and victory, instead of grief and sadness and defeat. When Ed next saw his friend, he asked to join their volunteer clown group. He's been with them for a number of years now - he says he never gets tired of doing it.  And he doesn't just visit the kids - he goes to see church members that are in the hospital, shut ins in their homes - all kinds of people, and he does it for free. He sure gave me a big boost the day I was walking down the hall of the hospital just hours after I'd had my gallbladder removed,  trying to get myself mobile so I could go home.  This big clown came lumbering up the hall, grabbed me gently, shook my hand with his clown buzzer, and made me laugh!  Made my belly hurt a little bit, but sure took my mind off the discomfort of walking!  I didn't even know who he was until he took his mask off.  Said he was on his way to see the kids, so I was thankful to have also gotten the benefit of his visit. If you feel up to it, maybe you could check out if there is a volunteer clown group in your neighborhood. I'm sure they'd be glad to have some help, as you feel able and comfortable. You don't have to be able to do anything special tricks, or wear a really fancy clown get up.  A painted smile and a funny nose, a floppy hat, and some baggy drawers - that gets good laughs, and sick kids sure do love getting a balloon, or a box of crayons and a coloring book.  And they sure get happy when the clown sits down and colors a picture with them, or reads a story to them. ( A lot of the adults seem to like the clowns, too.)  And you know how kids are - they can be quick to give back the love and kindness they receive.  Just like Ed:  therapy for them, therapy for you. Wishing you the best, Tre Tre: thankyou so much for your responce and very good advice.  I totally love the clown idea!  I dont know if there is such a thing here in my area but I will look into it.  The idea of dressing up and looking goofy and having the kids chuckle and have fun is such a great idea.  I will talk to officials here around town and see if they have people who do this already.  I know I need to get out and find my own things that will help take my mind off of my problems..I know that is my problem..I use to work retail years ago and havent worked for several years...I should go back to work..but then I wouldnt be ready available to take care of the little guy when I was needed..I guess I make myself to available to be hurt in a way.  I never thought I could be a person who could love to take care of little kids either..my grandson has changed that state of mind for me.  Not all kids are like him though..he is so easy to take care of..it makes it a joy and not a burden or a hair raising experience.  He is busy as all 3 year olds are, but he minds well, and I just have so much fun taking care of him.  He will probably be my only grandchild..my son and his wife arent having anymore..so this makes this little guy even more special..and unfortunately it makes them very protective of him to the point they are affraid to let him venture to far away from them.  I can totally understand their feelings, but they need to realize that I may not be here to watch this little guy grow up and get to a point he will remember the little things that I do for him now..I cant recall very much when I was 3..  I am not at deaths door by no means, but I know that stage lV brings a very grim outcome usually.  I am realistic about that..I do have a good attitude and most of the time I dont think about my illness or let it control me or paralize me.. I get out and do what ever I can to keep myself busy..but I just need to do more.  My grandson will be starting preschool soon which will make my time with him become even more few and far between.  I have offered to help with baking and craft making and such for classroom parties but this offer has fell on death ears.. no input from me is wanted or seemingly needed so all I can do is just back off and allow her to decide when she wants or needs the help.  Like you said, I need to find another avenue for my help.  I decorate cakes, and have always loved crafting, painting, sewing etc.  I loved it when my kids were in school and at the age I could do these things..they grow up way to fast!!  Well enough...but thankyou again for the helpful ideas..I love the clown one and will see about how I can use this idea around here...heck, I could sew and make the costume...that would be fun!!!  Sorry for the pitty party whiney stuff..I will be fine...just pull myself up by the bootstraps and get on with it..  I am a strong person usually, I just get down about this one aspect of my life and how things turn out so often with it.. I wanted to take my grandson this weekend out for lunch..I was so excited about it and I even asked my daughter in law to join us so she wouldnt be left out..but it fell on death ears..so that is why I am feeling so down about it right now..I just dont want to even ask anymore..rejection is hurtful..but I will be fine...just had to vent here..and thank you all so much for responding..it helps alot!! God's blessings...and hope your days are filled with good things! Jodie Hi Jodie My sister-in-law and brother-in-law have the same problem.  Their daughter-in-law only allows the children to come over on rare occasions - usually when she needs someone to babysit.  Unfortunately, few states have laws allowing a grandparent visitation rights and even then, it is only a rare visit for a short period.    Tre, as usual, has given you some excellent advice.  If there are no clown groups in the area, you could be the one to start one.  God layed it on Tre's heart to come up with the idea even after she responded to your post so maybe a clown group would benefit a great many children and even adults in your area.  Jodie, remember that while your grandson means the world to you and not seeing him is difficult - you also mean the world to your grandson and he NEEDS to see you - even if for one day a week or even once a month.  If he never had the opportunity to see or know you it would be tragic for him.  Should the clown group not work out, please look into being a grandparent to a child who is not fortunate enough to have one.  It might ease your pain as well as fill a hole in the child's heart.  We helped a family rebuild their home after Hurricane Charlie destroyed it and I became very close to the children (even though I have 5 children and 12 grandchildren of my own expecting #13).  Their dad eventually asked if I minded if the children looked to me as Grandma as only one had ever seen his grandparents (when he was 1 yr old - now 10) and the other two had never met their grandparents as the grandparents live in a different country.  Who knows, once your son and daughter-in-law see that you are able to take care of others, they might be more open to your having your grandson more.  I wish you the very best - please let us know how the clown group or surrogate grandparenting goes.    Diana
Posts.Title: grandson is my best chemo medicine

Posts.Content: On 8/14/2008 Jockey wrote: Hi Jodie, I am sorry for your dilemma. I would suggest you just enjoy the times that you have your grandson and cherish them.  I have 2 grandchildren and really adore them.  I have found the secret to having them around more is having a good relationship with their mothers.  Try to understand the mother's reasoning.  She is probably trying to protect her little boy from getting too attached then you probably leave him.  I think most of the parents' selfishness comes from being protective of their kids and not trying to be mean.   I lost my son to stomach cancer 2 weeks ago and appreciate life even more.  The times you have your grandchild are times to be cherished. When you don't have him, just plan on your next visit with him. I wish you well with yoiur health.. and wonderful times with your grandbaby..  God's blessings to you. Jockey Hi Jodie Have you heard anything back yet on the volunteering at the hospital.  I think you have a wonderful plan of volunteering first and then working your way into the clown group (which for you I am so excited about).  You know how I told you yesterday that I could God's hand all over Tre's suggestion of the clown group?  If she suggested to me - I would have said "No way" but she feels compelled to tell you and you say "Right on"!  Well consider God's hand still in it.  My thinking was a little along what Jockey's is - that possibly your daughter-in-law and maybe your son are concerned about your son getting too close to you OR maybe just wearing you out (as 3 yr olds can do).  While I was cleaning today I picked up a couple of books that I had with me 2 weeks ago when I was up at the Cancer Treatment Center of America.  I read a paper while there but for some "unknown" reason I tore one page out of it and stuck it in my book.  I pulled it out today and thought 'this would be good for Jodie'.  It is a Dear Abby column addressing this exact issue.  I tried to think how I could get it to you - go to the library and scan it and then email it to you, mail what I have to you, ????  Then I thought why not go to the website www.dearabby.com and see what I find.  Imagine my surprise when it was easy to locate as I have the date and headline of the column - July 31 - 'Encourage contact with boy's ailing granddad'.  In fact, there were a two more very good letters in the same column that didn't show up in the paper I have (2 were published in my paper).  Here is the link http://www.uexpress.com/dearabby/index.html?uc_full_date=200 I'm sure your son is a nice young man as he is your son and I'm sure he loves you.  Just a suggestion because you know your son whereas all of us do not but have you tried talking to him and asking him why they don't bring your little guy over for you to see more often or let you take him for outings?  They may be concerned he is too much for you to handle with your illness (which your volunteering should alieve those fears).  They may be concerned about him getting too close to you and feel they are protecting him from a loss later in life which would be sad for both you and him.  Maybe the letters in Dear Abby would help your son and daughter-in-law to see a different viewpoint - one of the letters is actually from the grandchildren who later in life found out that their parents had "shielded" them from getting hurt and how they felt about it.  As I said, I thought they were very good letters/responses.  I know one respondent suggested a journal which is a tremendous idea - In fact, I think I will start one myself.  I would cherish a journal written by my grandmother.  She also suggested finding an article she named and giving it to your son and daughter-in-law.  Only you know them - would they consider this interfering in their parenting.  I have given artlcles/books to my daughters but I did something similar with my son years ago and it was not well received.  I was thinking about your question as to what do clowns do?  As I was mulling it over last night I remembered my dad's days of being a Shriner - they had clowns.  So I googled Shiners clowns and came up with a ton of articles.  Maybe if you have a local Shriners Association you could explain to them what you want to do and they might be help you.  Just a thought!!  Please let us know what you hear back on the volunteer work.  What an inspiration that would be to so many of us on this forum.  You already have me looking ahead to what I can get involved in.  I can just envision how much happiness you could bring into so many lives by being a clown.  Take care sweetie and remember God loves you and is watching over you - of that I have no doubt! Diana
Posts.Title: grandson is my best chemo medicine

Posts.Content: On Jan 22, 2015 11:45 AM Bugs4you wrote: Hi Linda, I read your article and I am truly sorry you are going through any of this. My mother went through similar of what you are and in Oct (2013) she went into the emergency room because she had a lump in her breast that she thought was a boil. When the first doctor looked at it they suspected it could have been breast cancer and wanted her to get more tests. My mother went back the next day for another doctors opinion and he ended up lancing it because he said it was a boil. About 8 months later it grew back and my mother once again got it checked and they got a biopsy and confirmed it was cancer. They started her on Chemo (my mother weighs 98 lbs.) and gave her over 15 different meds. The chemo weakened her immune system and her heart and she ended up having to get a blood transfusion to improve her T-Cells. They released my mom from the hospital about 4 days later. Because of the extensive chemo and all of the meds my mother was back in the hospital about 5 days after her blood transfusion suffering with 4 heart attacks within 2 days as well as a seizure which landed her in ICU for a week and in the hospital for 2 weeks after. She recently had surgery for a permanant pacemaker and by the grace of Lord she survived it all and is now taking chemo pills which are shrinking the cancer and is planning on getting the mastectomy in June. My mother almost passed away because of poor negligence caused by an incompetent doctor who never even took a biopsy to test the lump for cancer. I thought most doctors should know these kind of things. It upsets me that women like yourself and my mother have to go through these kinds of things when a doctor should be trained and know how to diagnose someone especially when it's an evident suspicion. I really am praying for you and keep hope alive like my mother. Lots of love, Reg :) Hi We always welcome newcomers to Cancer Compass because it is truly a cyber family that is here to support each other.  CC has been around for many years and we find blogs are often revived when someone reads a particular post.  This particular blog was written in early 2009.  Linda may not respond to your post because it has been six years since she posted - and so much can happen in six years.  I pray she is doing well wherever she is.  I truly understand your frustration.  I had a different type of cancer (tonsil) and my only symptom in the beginning was extreme fatique.  I went to 5 doctors in seven weeks and all found no reason for my fatique.  Finally, I began having very mild chest pains - only bothered me at night when I went to bed.  My father had an extensive heart disease problem so I asked for a referral to a cardiologist.  She took a look in my mouth and said "We need to get you to an ENT immediately and they may want to biopsy that."  That was Monday - Wed evening I saw the ENT who looked in my mouth and said "Holy Mackeral".  I was in surgery the following Mon AM and biopsy showed cancer before I even left the operating room. A very dear friend of mine - sisters by choice since we were 3 years old, had a very similar experience as your mother.  She was diagnosed with cancer and had a double mastectomy.  A little over a year later she had a "boil" come up in one armpit.  The doctor lanced it and told her that it was no problem.  Several months went by and the area got continually worse.  Her husband finally told her she was going to a specialist - who diagnosed her with advanced cancer.  She was told early on that it was so far advanced it was incurable.  They sued the doctor and won a huge settlement but as she told me, she would have given it all back for good health.  After seven years of fighting this horrible disease the second time (nine including the first battle), she passed away this past Dec 20.  She had a deep faith in God and I know she celebrated Jesus birthday with Him but we all miss her.  She was a HUGE inspiration to so many!!  Prayers for everyone Cancer Compass.  I can tell you are going to be a valuable member of our family - caring, knowledgeable, and sharing.  We may not cross paths often because I am rarely on the breast cancer section except to share Brenda's story.  I have been contributing to the oral cancer section for 7 1/2 years - cancer free!!! Praise God! Diana
Posts.Title: misdiagnosis?!?!?!

Posts.Content: On 8/14/2008 Jockey wrote: Hi Jodie, I am sorry for your dilemma. I would suggest you just enjoy the times that you have your grandson and cherish them.  I have 2 grandchildren and really adore them.  I have found the secret to having them around more is having a good relationship with their mothers.  Try to understand the mother's reasoning.  She is probably trying to protect her little boy from getting too attached then you probably leave him.  I think most of the parents' selfishness comes from being protective of their kids and not trying to be mean.   I lost my son to stomach cancer 2 weeks ago and appreciate life even more.  The times you have your grandchild are times to be cherished. When you don't have him, just plan on your next visit with him. I wish you well with yoiur health.. and wonderful times with your grandbaby..  God's blessings to you. Jockey Hi Jodie Have you heard anything back yet on the volunteering at the hospital.  I think you have a wonderful plan of volunteering first and then working your way into the clown group (which for you I am so excited about).  You know how I told you yesterday that I could God's hand all over Tre's suggestion of the clown group?  If she suggested to me - I would have said "No way" but she feels compelled to tell you and you say "Right on"!  Well consider God's hand still in it.  My thinking was a little along what Jockey's is - that possibly your daughter-in-law and maybe your son are concerned about your son getting too close to you OR maybe just wearing you out (as 3 yr olds can do).  While I was cleaning today I picked up a couple of books that I had with me 2 weeks ago when I was up at the Cancer Treatment Center of America.  I read a paper while there but for some "unknown" reason I tore one page out of it and stuck it in my book.  I pulled it out today and thought 'this would be good for Jodie'.  It is a Dear Abby column addressing this exact issue.  I tried to think how I could get it to you - go to the library and scan it and then email it to you, mail what I have to you, ????  Then I thought why not go to the website www.dearabby.com and see what I find.  Imagine my surprise when it was easy to locate as I have the date and headline of the column - July 31 - 'Encourage contact with boy's ailing granddad'.  In fact, there were a two more very good letters in the same column that didn't show up in the paper I have (2 were published in my paper).  Here is the link http://www.uexpress.com/dearabby/index.html?uc_full_date=200 I'm sure your son is a nice young man as he is your son and I'm sure he loves you.  Just a suggestion because you know your son whereas all of us do not but have you tried talking to him and asking him why they don't bring your little guy over for you to see more often or let you take him for outings?  They may be concerned he is too much for you to handle with your illness (which your volunteering should alieve those fears).  They may be concerned about him getting too close to you and feel they are protecting him from a loss later in life which would be sad for both you and him.  Maybe the letters in Dear Abby would help your son and daughter-in-law to see a different viewpoint - one of the letters is actually from the grandchildren who later in life found out that their parents had "shielded" them from getting hurt and how they felt about it.  As I said, I thought they were very good letters/responses.  I know one respondent suggested a journal which is a tremendous idea - In fact, I think I will start one myself.  I would cherish a journal written by my grandmother.  She also suggested finding an article she named and giving it to your son and daughter-in-law.  Only you know them - would they consider this interfering in their parenting.  I have given artlcles/books to my daughters but I did something similar with my son years ago and it was not well received.  I was thinking about your question as to what do clowns do?  As I was mulling it over last night I remembered my dad's days of being a Shriner - they had clowns.  So I googled Shiners clowns and came up with a ton of articles.  Maybe if you have a local Shriners Association you could explain to them what you want to do and they might be help you.  Just a thought!!  Please let us know what you hear back on the volunteer work.  What an inspiration that would be to so many of us on this forum.  You already have me looking ahead to what I can get involved in.  I can just envision how much happiness you could bring into so many lives by being a clown.  Take care sweetie and remember God loves you and is watching over you - of that I have no doubt! Diana
Posts.Title: grandson is my best chemo medicine

Posts.Content: On 8/28/2008 Arnold wrote: My dearest sister passed away from reocurring breast cancer this morning.  She is with our Lord Jesus and is no longer suffering.  These last 6 months were full of hope but it just didn't work out.  She was 75. Arnold I know how devastated you are over the loss of your big sister but it is comforting to know a loved one is with our Lord and no longer suffering.  I will continue to remember you and your family in my prayers.  Please take care of yourself as stress is not our friend. Diana
Posts.Title: My Dearest Sister Passed away

Posts.Content: Hi K If you heard a cheer just now that was just me - way to go girl (and hubby)!  I am so happy that you spoke to your husband.  When I said my money was on him to come through - I knew that was a pretty safe bet.  When you go back to work and someone asks you how you are doing you can just tell them you are okay and thank you for asking.  I'm sure they are concerned but you don't need to talk about it if you choose not to.  Keep us updated on how you are doing.  Diana
Posts.Title: thank you

Posts.Content: My 44 year old daughter has had two lumps in her breast for a couple of years.  Routine mamograms showed no malignancy.  A couple of months ago, she discovered a third lump and went in for a routine mamogram.  The report came back saying there had been no change in the two lumps and considered stable.  We both asked how there could be no change when she could no palpate a third lump.  She has been experiencing intense fatigue and pain - which is so unlike my "tough" daughter who has been through a lot without complaint.  About a month ago, she noticed purple veins running through on breast down to the nipple.  This morning she woke up with dimples in one breast surrounded by red skin that was hot to the touch.  She also has discovered a lump in her pelvic area.  The doctor she was seeing in her small town believed it was all hormonal and didn't believe it necessary to send her on for an MRI.  Has anyone had these symptoms - veins running through the breast, dimpling, redness, and heat in one breast.  A friend who has been battling breast cancer for six years told me that fever in the breast was one symptom she had just prior to her diagnosis.  I am trying to get my daughter to see a specialist but she has an appointment with a clinic on Wed hoping to get an order for an MRI so her insurance covers it. Diana
Posts.Title: New Developments in Breast

Posts.Content: Bibi - All doctors involved seemed to have given up at this point and are waiting until mid October for the next biopsy.  My grandmother lost all three of her children before she died and told me when I had to break the news to her that my mother had passed that she hoped and prayed I never found out what it was like to lose a child.  While it was frustrating to go from doctor to doctor to doctor before finding one that knew I had tonsil cancer it was nothing compared to what I am feeling now knowing that something is terribly wrong with my daughter AND that there aren't any doctors that can pinpoint what it is.  Before I was diagnosed with cancer I thought all doctors were equally as good - or close anyway.  I went to five doctors that didn't have a clue why I was so tired all the time before finally finding one (cardiologist) that knew as soon as she looked at my greatly enlarged left tonsil, that I had cancer.  That was a wake up call - and then seeing all the posts on here where others have experienced the same I now realize that there are doctors who graduate at the top of their class and others who barely squeak through.  As my daughter who is a nurse said, the really good doctors generally go to areas where they can make more money.  Rarely do they go to a small town or small hospital.  SO TRUE!!  Not always but generally it is the case. There hasn't been an MRI or PET Scans done which is really frustrating.  When one was asked for, she was told that they couldn't order one until something showed up on the CAT Scan to warrant it.  Yet the third lump in her breast was not even mentioned in the results of the CAT scan.  As I said, very frustrating.   Thanks for inquiring Bibi!  As a Mom, I have to contain my concerns for her enough so I don't scare her more but show them just enough to push her into pressing forward.   It helps to have a place to vent my fears here.    Diana
Posts.Title: New Developments in Breast

Posts.Content: Whenever there is even a tiny possibiliy of there being a potential problem, it is good to have it checked out by your oncologist.  A close friend had a double mastectomy 9 years ago after being diagnosed with breast cancer.  A year later she had a lump appear under her arm.  She went to her doctor who lanced it and said no problem.  A year later she still had a problem and her husband ordered her to the doctor - a different one this time who sent her for a biopsy of the lump.  It turned out to be breast cancer.  She actually had one type of breast cancer on one side and another on the other side.  She was told early on that the cancer had a strong hold on her due to the delay in diagnosis and that it would one day take her life.  She endured treatment for 7 years - the last two basically being a guinea pig for new experimental chemo drugs in the hopes of helping other women who would one day be diagnosed.  Brenda passed away this past Dec 20 but would still be with us if not misdiagnosed.  Insist on whatever tests are needed so you know for sure what you are dealing with.  I had known Brenda since she was 3 years old - we were sisters by choice and started kindergarten together.  It is difficult to comprehend that due to a doctor's wrong diagnosis she is no longer with us.  She sued and won a large settlement against the doctor but she once told me she would give it all back to be cancer free.  Praying for good results.  Diana
Posts.Title: Advice needed

Posts.Content: dennisluke is just the latest name used by this scammer.  He/she posted eleven times last night under one female name - nine times last night under another female name (with different pictures for each) - and six times today so far under dennisluke. Yesterday it claimed to be a female whose mother encouraged her to use the hemp oil.  The other was a patients whose friend encouraged her - now it is the wife who is the patient.   A scammer attempting to take advantage of cancer patients on a site created by the Cancer Treatment Centers of America to help patients. It keeps Cancer Compass mediator working overtime to keep up with his scams.  Diana
Posts.Title: Advice needed

Posts.Content: gray steve1 - Are you saying that you are an employee of CTCA or did you copy something from their website?  While every word that you wrote is true, this is the first time in my 8 years on CC that I have seen a reply that indicates it was written by someone from CTCA - and this is your first post on CC.  Also, the person who posted this has breast cancer and I responded to her post as a survivor of tonsil cancer.  You wrote that brain cancer is life changing - which it is but not mentioned in this blog.    Diana
Posts.Title: Cancer treatment centers of America

Posts.Content: On Sep 04, 2013 10:31 PM svicky wrote: On Aug 06, 2013 1:29 AM Dlynn1210 wrote: My 44 year old daughter has had two lumps in her breast for a couple of years.  Routine mamograms showed no malignancy.  A couple of months ago, she discovered a third lump and went in for a routine mamogram.  The report came back saying there had been no change in the two lumps and considered stable.  We both asked how there could be no change when she could no palpate a third lump.  She has been experiencing intense fatigue and pain - which is so unlike my "tough" daughter who has been through a lot without complaint.  About a month ago, she noticed purple veins running through on breast down to the nipple.  This morning she woke up with dimples in one breast surrounded by red skin that was hot to the touch.  She also has discovered a lump in her pelvic area.  The doctor she was seeing in her small town believed it was all hormonal and didn't believe it necessary to send her on for an MRI.  Has anyone had these symptoms - veins running through the breast, dimpling, redness, and heat in one breast.  A friend who has been battling breast cancer for six years told me that fever in the breast was one symptom she had just prior to her diagnosis.  I am trying to get my daughter to see a specialist but she has an appointment with a clinic on Wed hoping to get an order for an MRI so her insurance covers it. Diana    any development on your daughter? I appreciate your asking.  Keeping in mind that this is the daughter (I have 4) that has never even let us know when something was going on with her, I am extremely worried about her because she is sharing what is going on!  I can tell she is very frightened - and it takes a lot to scare her.  The doctors have finally admitted they don't have a clue.  Everything seems to center on the left side (left breast, left ovary, left pelvic area).  Here are some things going on: 1) A sizeable lump 2" below her belly button.  They did an ultrasound of the pelvic area but said the area where the lump is located is not considered the pelvic area (what?).  It costs her $700 to be told sorry, "we couldn't examine the area we should have because it was a inch away from what WE consider the pelvic area."  2) She is waking up during the night with her right ear stopped up and left ear hurting.  Once she sits up, it subsides. 3) Her left ovary is twice the size of her right ovary.  4) They did a biopsy and said it was inconclusive for lupus.  They did a second biopsy and said it was also inconslusive.  They will do another biopsy in mid October.  I appreciate my Cancer Compass family's input.  You were always there for me when I was undergoing treatment for tonsil cancer.  I had excellent care at CTCA but from reading so many posts on here from others received inadequate care, I don't want to hear one day that I am going to lose my daughter because of the incompetence of some doctors who didn't have a clue. Diana
Posts.Title: New Developments in Breast

Posts.Content: On Jun 22, 2014 2:24 PM alicekay wrote: As a Christian I'm more than a little surprised at the harsh words and judgment toward Breast Ca4. This woman has terminal cancer and as Christians we should be showing her love, kindness and respect regardless of what she believes. I will pray for love and understanding. 1 John 4:7  Beloved, let us love one another, for love is from God, and whoever loves has been born of God and knows God.  Alicekay - As you said yourself, we are not here to judge but as Christians we are not asked but "instructed" to share God's words with others. I read back through the posts and don't see any harsh words or judgements from anyone except Breatr Ca4. I have been involved in the mission field for many years and what I shared and what others shared were encouragements to a woman who may well be facing the end of her life in a short time - a woman who doesn't know God. As Christians we are not judging but praying for her that she does come to know our Heavenly Father while she still can. She obviously didn't want to hear anything about God or read scriptures. We know that we will not touch everyone but we are doing as God and his son instructed us to do. Perhaps, the fact that she left was a good indication that our words were having an effect on her because that means there is still hope. We may be the first, second, or third stepping stone leading to her salvation. We never know when something said will click some time in the future if not now. Everyone here showed her kindness, love, and respect even though it was not returned. To sit back and say nothing would be have been disobedient to God - and especially important to speak up in light of her poor prognosis. .................................................................................................................................................... Mark 14-15. 14 - Afterward He appeared to the eleven themselves as they were reclining at the table; and He reproached them for their unbelief and hardness of heart, because they had not believed those who had seen Him after He had risen. 15 - and He said to them, "Go into all the world and preach the gospel to all creation. .................................................................................................................................................... We did as Jesus instructs us to several times in the Bible - we took the time to share the Gospel with her - possibly the only time she will have the opportunity to hear it. ....................................According to her, she didn't want to hear any God crap and that is why she left but somewhere down the line she may rethink her position about God................. I have found that at times Christians can be the hardest on and most judgmental of other Christians but then no human being is perfect. Have a blessed day alicekay. ............... Diana
Posts.Title: Best friend has stage 4 cancer - getting worse. I'm lost.

We did as Jesus instructs us to several times in the Bible - we took the time to share the Gospel with her - possibly the only time she will have the opportunity to hear it. ....................................According to her, she didn't want to hear any God crap and that is why she left but somewhere down the line she may rethink her position about God................. I have found that at times Christians can be the hardest on and most judgmental of other Christians but then no human being is perfect. Have a blessed day alicekay. ............... Diana There is a difference between instructing God's words with others and being judgmental and cruel . “I hope you find my words helpful as you prepare for you own annihilation.” “ It's rude to turn this into your problem and start policing the comments.” “It's merely a satanic attack. “ “There is no need to respond back because it will just prompt other Christians to share the Gospel with you “  “If you are looking for a argumentative discussion on theology, I suggest you find a site where life is not so fragile and where your hurtful words will not harm those in the weakest moments in their lives. “ This woman has cancer and has the right to feel however she feels. As Christians we need to love everyone regardless of their beliefs and the God I believe in is a kind and loving God. It is people like you and others on this thread that give true Christians a bad name. I will pray that the people here can see the error of their ways. Praise God. alicekay, Spoken as a true Christian!  The "satanic attack" comment made by others was upsetting to me also.  I am a Christian and being a Christian has been of great comfort to me and my family. Getting religious advice and comfort from someone I know is always welcome, especially when I ask for it.  I don't need nor want any anonymous witnessings or preaching.   To bring up religion and then refer to a non- believer's comment as a satanic attack is wrong.  These internet cancer Christians need to spend more time in church and less time on CC.  Charles Charles - before bowing out of this discussion, I would like to make one comment in response to your post. I was not the one who wrote satanic attack but it sounds as if I interpreted it differently than you and alice did. When we are not the author, we often don't understand the meaning behind certain words. We can take words differently than what someone meant. I did not understand satanic attack to mean breast's comment but rather that very often when God's words are offered, Satan tries to counter those words and undermine God's work! That happens frequently - I have very close friends who are missionaries and dedicating their life to The Lord outside the U.S. The more good they see from the fruits of their labor, the more Satan worked against them. This went on for a year but as we all know, we've read the book and know who wins in the end. Diana
Posts.Title: Best friend has stage 4 cancer - getting worse. I'm lost.

Posts.Content: On Jun 19, 2014 4:06 PM BreastCA4 wrote: I am not sure if the last post is in the right thread. Stage 4 cancer is terminal. I have stage 4 and I am not deluding myself thinking GOD will provide a "cure", If that magical thinking is comforting to you, indulge yourself. I don't find any of that GOD crap useful, helpful or worth a second of my time. This is a real thread about dying, I doubt you have ill intent, but please take it somewhere else.I am always very sorry for those who are in your position. I am referring to anyone who is facing a serious dilemma - whether it be a life altering situation or a life threatening disease. I lost my husband to lung cancer and I was given a 50/50 chance for survival 7 years ago after being diagnosed with tonsil cancer stage 4. If I had been in your position either time, I would have fallen apart - probably yelled at the world - but I know that there is a god - my Heavenly Father and I relied on Him to get me through both times - and He did! ................................................................................................................................................. This thread is not about dying but living - however much time we have left - and no one is assured of an exact time. I could be involved in a fatal car accident today - as could anyone. The Cancer Treatment Centers of Ameica created and sponsor Cancer Compass. Their motto - "God didn't give you an expiration date and we won't either". God is important to CTCA and is important to many here. They hold Sunday services in chapels located in their facilities. They are all about what is best for ALL patients and there are many of us that take comfort in knowing that God is there for us. God can perform miracles and has but what is more important than living is knowing where I will be after death. So while you may think that god is a lot of nonsense - a great many more know better. ................................................................................................................................................... One question that you don't need to answer. What if you are right and I am wrong about God. What is the worst that can happen when I die? I will be buried in a grave! On the other side, what happens if you are wrong and I, and all others who believe in Him, are right? The Bible is very clear on the consequences of denying God. And that my friend is a position that I wouldn't want to be in - to be wrong about whether God exists or not. I don't expect to make an impact on you here but then God instructs us to share His words with others. We have free will and it is up to them as to what they do with those words. There is no need to respond back because it will just prompt other Christians to share the Gospel with you. Diana

Posts.Content: I totally agree. It has been 8 years since my diagnosis and I began treatment in August 2007 at CTCA in Zion. I also live in FL now but still go back every year for my checkup - due back in Sept. Dr. Citrin is the best and CTCA is one of the most caring facilities one could ask for. Everyone from the nurses to the lab techs to the cafeteria workers - everyone cares and shows their support. My husband had to travel from Monday through Friday every week while I was undergoing treatment. CTCA became my family and my support system. Diana
Posts.Title: Cancer treatment centers of America

Posts.Content: On Aug 04, 2011 6:38 PM Easterling wrote: On Jul 23, 2011 1:56 PM Connie64 wrote: On Jul 17, 2011 6:51 PM sjk1963 wrote: On Jul 17, 2011 3:26 PM GramNurse wrote: thanks for responding. I know I am just overwhelmed. I was totally ok until finding out I have to take chemo... I am 54, working fulltime, in school, 2 quarters away from completing a degree as a Nurse Practitioner and my plate is already way too full.  To have this... just not good.  I will push forward... I have no choice.  My mother died from colon and lung cancer 21 days after diagnosis... I will not let that happen to me! Don't do something you don't know enough about. I have good info. for you. Check your notifications I am curious. Why are you against anything medical to treat cancer? I see your replies in a lot of posts and you are always telling people not to get treatment. Why? I do not know if this was meant for me or not but I have an answer to this regardless. I do not judge anyone who decides to have surgery or chemo or what ever. But if one can be healed with out the harmfulness of chemo or radiation and being cut on would you do that? I was diagnosed with breast, lymph cancer. It had spreaad to my lungs and liver. I went the alternative way and do not regret it in the least. I am on Protocel and other things that go with it for a little over a month now. The tumor has shrunk, the lymph nodes also and the pain in my liver is gone. I feel great. My energy is wonderful again.  If one opts surgery then I wish them the best. I still have the body parts the God blessed me with. I was in stage 3.......God BlessPat - I know you mean well and while I am not 100 percent agains alternative treatment (especially in addition to conventional treatment), I think it is a little early to be encouraging people to forgo chemo and radiation. What if your words caused someone to refuse chemo and radiation and instead go with Protocel - AND that person dies? You have only been on Protocl yourself for a little over a month. How do you know it is a cure? The brain is a powerful organ and the placebo effect is a shining example of that.

Posts.Title: New Diagnosis

Posts.Content: On 1/28/2008 Leemg wrote: Before having radiation several years ago I mentioned to my radiation oncologist that I was concerned because I had such sensitive skin.  She gave me Biafine cream for radiated areas and this helped to keep down the redness.  By the end of my treatments my breast was pink but I avoided the extreme redness and discomfort that goes along with it. I also used Biafine Topical Emulsion and my brother as well.  We were diagnosed just months apart and we both wound up w/ severe radiation burns.  I found out about the cream from a cancer magazine and asked my oncologist for a prescription.  I told my brother about it but his oncologist had already prescribed it for him.  It worked wonders for both of us but is quite expensive.  I got a large tube .90b and if I remember right it cost $48 at WaL Mart (although it is worth every penny of it when you are burned raw).  It states on the box and the directions that it is for use for radiation dermatitis.  It also instructs not to use it for 4 hours before radiation but I was told not to use any cream prior to radiation.  My oncologist said it rejuvenates the damaged cells.  Diana
Posts.Title: Treatment Of Radiation Burns

Posts.Content: It's interesting that you should word it that way - afterlife insurance because our belief in God is insurance of an afterlife (eternal life) but more importantly, it is assurance of a way of life while here. You are absolutely right about Emily's question but I have a best friend since 4th grade and know that Emily has the same type of relationship that I have with my friend. I just drove five hours one way to spend a few days with her while she was recuperating from gall bladder surgery. She flew up to stay with me while undergoing treatment for cancer. We are there to hold each other's hands and listen to each other through whatever comes our way - good and bad. We are sisters by choice rather than birth. ...................................................... I was a stage 4 patient given a 50/50 chance of survival. My now husband (we were planning a wedding when diagnosed which I put on hold since I didn't want to die and leave him with a ton of bills) said I was unbelievably calm throughout treatment. I cried once when thinking about not being here to see my grandbaby who was born half way through tx grow up. I was sad for her - not me! You see, in the beginning I had handed everything over to God - my prayer was that if it be His Will that my time here was done, I totally accepted that and was at peace with it. Also, that if He saw me through treatment I would do even more in His name! God was with me every step of the way. ........................................................................ I have a close friend who has been living with terminal cancer for 7 years. She had a double mastectomy 7 years ago and was clear for one year before being diagnosed with two different types of breast cancer (one started as a lump under her armpit). They have told her point blank that she will never be free of cancer - that it will one day take her life. Her daughter drives her 300 miles round trip for treatment every Tuesday. When I left her last fall, I really didn't think I would see her again she looked so bad. When I came back a few months later I was shocked to see how upbeat she was. She is totally bald but has numerous wigs that she can put on at any time and be ready to go. We had a wig fashion show, we went out to dinner and laughed all night, and then we returned home for a sleep over. She now has injections in her hip once a week that leave her SORE but yet, she thanks God each and every day for giving her another day to enjoy her family, her many friends, and counsel other cancer patients. She is an amazing amazing amazing woman! .............................................. The requirement to believe in God and the way to have eternal life is not just my way but God's way and the many who out their total faith in Him. I beg to differ with you about no other post is there god talk because it is found continually through all posts over all types of cancer on Cancer Compass. I am in the right spot - and maybe so are you. I am not being cruel here but everyone is going to die - we just don't know when our time here will be up - it could be today for any of us! When I ask unbelievers or those who are not followers of Christ what happens if you are right and I am wrong about God - I truly hope one thinks about that. If I was wrong, the worst that would happen is nothing - I would die and someone would bury me. But of I am right and you are wrong, I will gain eternal life and be united with family that left years ago AND you will spend eternity in place described so horribly in the Bible that one don't even want to think about it! ...........I look around at our world today and I'm beginning to see what that place will look like - and it is ugly and with no hope of it getting better.. Your eternal soul depends on researching our claims. Lee Strobel did not believe in God but after his wife became a believer, this professional writer set out to prove there was no God. Instead he found information that proved otherwise. He spoke to atheist and to clergymen of different faiths. Remember he set out to prove his wife wrong to get her out of this crazy Christianity. His research proved to him that there is a god - our God! ................................................................................................................... Satan was referenced because where God is at work, we always find Satan trying to undermine God's work. Diana
Posts.Title: Best friend has stage 4 cancer - getting worse. I'm lost.

Posts.Content: On Oct 29, 2011 3:48 PM thebyrdsfriend wrote: I think you've missed the point Shemay.  The alternative treatment board is where all this should be.  And if you think the subject line should ward off those who don't want or need to read about these alternative treatments, you are wrong.  What part of - Tired of pink ribbons? - points to a thread about alternative treatments?  There is a special section just for those posts.  If we feel the need to seek out those discussions, then that is the section we will click on. I'm glad someone understood. I thought I had clarified that Amdy's input about vitamins and treatment involving vitamin therapy may be welcomed on the alternative section but maybe I wasn't as clear as I thought. I find Andy has been posting since April, 2010 which allows a young man 1 1/2 years to research cancer in general (admits he is a researcher and never a cancer patient) and become an expert! I am a cancer survivor of tonsil cancer and have researched in terms of years, as has Sheila (Shemay) and many others when it is our lives on the line - or a spouse or child- but I would NEVER attempt to tell someone with different type of cancer how to treat. I had a type of cancer that if left untreated would have taken my life. I am NOT adverse to alternative treatment but personally I am not going to become the guinea pig for an alternative treatment when there is a tried and true conventional treatment that has been proven time and again. I do visit the alternative site and Sheila helped to convince me that Vit C injectable has some value; however, I did not - and do not want - to join a political fight against any non-profit organization OR any doctors. We cannot become so defensive of our OWN opinions that we begin to hurt those that we want to help. THIS forum was not created as a stage to fight a political battle. The only statement that I have heard that was more stupid than "men can't get breast cancer" is the statement by Pelosi that we should pass the healthcare bill and THEN read it! No matter what stand you take, you should read anything before voting to support or not to support an issue. I so totally agree about pink ribbons not having anything to do with treatment - alternative or conventional! It is an emblem used to promote breast cancer awareness. Diana
Posts.Title: Importance of Vit D & Breast C

Posts.Content: On Oct 29, 2011 2:54 PM Shemay wrote: Andy    I support you 100%.   You have such a giving heart. I have followed your posts for years now and I have learned a great deal from the research you have done.  I consider you an asset to the Cancercompass site and I know of many others who feel the same way and acknowledge and appreciate your dedication to helping others.  The anger and disrespect some members feel entitled to display towards those  who hold alternative views to their's is very disturbing to me.   Rudeness and personal attacks are not in the least bit helpful to anyone.  Perhaps some anger or frustration is released for the poster doing that  type of venting but  anyone with any type of sensitivity  is negatively affected by reading those messages.   The emotions caused by these types of posts are not health promoting.   Perhaps it would be wise to wait a half hour or so after composing a reply to something one finds disturbing before clicking on the send button.  That way  common sense and our inherent human sense of fairness  will have time to calm down the initial reactions and then responses could reflect that. I'm sure by now it is obvious to most members (certainly the ones commenting on this thread)  that posts made by Andy and others like he and myself are going to be regarding alternative protocols that our experience and research have taught us are effective.  So another solution would be to just skip by them.  That way no negative feelings will be aroused nor need to be expressed. Peace and good health everyoneSheila - You know how much I respect the views of those who hold to alternative treatment - and to your rights to your opinions - even when I totally disagree with those views. The times I totally disagree with having alternative treatments pushed down our throats is when someone who adamantly believes in alternative treatment tries to tell someone who has cancer that conventional is wrong or an agency trying to help them is only in it for the money OR their doctors are lying them. Especially when that patient if not treated with a conventional treatment is going to lose his/her battle. This is not the purpose of CC although there are most definitely sites for this very purpose. The alternative section on CC was created for those who adhere to alternative TREATMENTS. You may have seen Andy on other sites but it appears he has only been on CC since 2010 when he admitted he had a friend who had cancer but never experienced it himself - and sadly, personal experience is the best teacher! How much about every type of cancer can you learn in 1 and 1/2 years? Every type of cancer is so different that I would never never never attempt to give medical advice to anyone who is living with a different type than I personally experienced. For instance, Andy said previously that there is no such thing as a reoccurrence? There is a whole lot more that goes along with that than a mere statement and the one simple statement alone if accepted can be detrimental to a cancer patient. Anything else I post will be private replies because those battling cancer don't need the stress of a heated discussion - AND after all, this site is to help them (and that includes reducing their stress). Unless you are open to alternative treatments, anything said on this site or any other site is going to convince you of their effectiveness. You convinced me that vitamin c injections have some merit - not because you told me that a nonprofit was after my money OR my doctor was holding out on me BUT by giving me information - educating me! I am open to alternative but not used in place of conventional. The one main thing I loved about CTCA - their combining both. Diana Diana
Posts.Title: Importance of Vit D & Breast C
