Diana DianaI would like to clarify - the majority of the time when I reply, if you read my posts closely, I am not objecting to what is being said or your right to say it but where it is being said. CANCER COMPASS was created as a way for us to help cancer patients navigate their journey through cancer. I could care less about what nonprofit was doing what to whom and what pharmaceutical company was making the most money when I was losing the love of my life to lung cancer. I didn't have cancer compass to turn to as I watched my husband wither away before my eyes. When I was being treated for cancer, I could care less about political issues. I came to hear from the survivors who cheered me on, the ones who said you can do this. When the entire side of my face went numb and my visiting nurse freaked out, I turned to my CC family who reassured me that it was a side effect of radiation because it had happened to them. I may even agree with something being said but disagree as to where it is being posted because I know where my mind set was as a caregiver and as a patient! We shouldn't become so focused on our own beliefs that we lose sight of the fact that members here are dealing with far more serious issues that have nothing to do with our opinions on a subject! Diana
Posts.Title: Importance of Vit D & Breast C

Posts.Content: On 7/9/2008 tomslady wrote: I am right there with you. I basically have benn going through the same thing. Found a lump, no show on the mammogram but did show on ultrasound, gave me 3 weeks to have it removed. June 13th  had a surgical biopsy in 2 weeks, it was invasive ductal carcinoma and had my lumpectomy with sentinal lobe disection done on July 2nd. Surgeon says she got it all and it had not spread so now I am in limbo waiting to go to the oncologist and find out chemo or radiation or both.  I am 38, married a year for the 2nd time have 3 gorgeous children and am scared to death. i told my husband today who is the main reason i am fighting this that i don't want to do anything else. Just let me go. I am becoming more depressed as time goes on and I know it is awesome that it hasn't spread and it isn't in both breasts but the thought of chemo and what you have to go through and I found out today that chemo will throw me in to menapause and truley my new husband and i were hoping to have a child of our own he does not have any children and I was hoping to be the mther of his first child. I waited all my life to find a love like this and I feel i am being short changed and that i am short changing him, he didn't sign up for this and now he is suffering to.   I hope your test comes out with good news and sorry to ramble on I just read your message and started to cry because I literally know what you are going through right now and it is not easy.  Keep us posted. Hi Tomslady - I have a different type of cancer so I can't address your treatment but I would like to say I can feel your pain.  As a 60 yr old, I called my step mother shortly after being told by my ENT that she was sure I had tonsil cancer and cried because I was so scared - so being scared is a natural reaction.  I encourage you to do whatever it takes to ensure you beat this - for yourself, for your husband, and for your three gorgeous children that need their mother.  You said your husband didn't sign up for this - but when we get married no one says it is always going to be perfect.  As my father once said, young people today don't understand that every marriage has good times and bad times - and it is the good times that get you through the bad AND it's those bad times that make the good times even better.  As for having children, talk to you doctor and tell him how you feel.  There may be something that can be done but if it comes to your never having children with the love of your life, then you both will enjoy the three you have.  I have a daughter that was told at 22 that there was a good possibility that she would never be able to get pregnant.  When she met a young man several years later who asked her to marry him, she told him no because they might never have children (which he wanted badly).  He told her it was her he wanted and if there were no children - well so be it.  They were married and 3 years later went through invitro and have twin boys - now 5 yrs.  Please don't sell your new husband short regarding your children.  They are a part of the woman he loves.  My first husband decided he preferred the single life when I was pregnant w/ my 5th child and walked out on us.  I met a man when my youngest was 7 mo. and my oldest was 7 yrs.  We were married when the youngest was 3.  Sadly, we lost him to lung cancer shortly after the baby turned 18 yrs but 3 yrs later when her sister talked her into going to a family reunion (biological father's) she told her biological father that he wasn't her father - that her real father had passed away (so a close bond can exist between a child and stepfather).  You fell in love with this man so I'm sure he is very special - give him a chance to show you how wonderful and supportive he can be through this trying time.  Marriage is being there for each other and there will be good times again!  I had only known my present husband 4 years when I was diagnosed w/ my cancer and we grew even closer through our battle w/ cancer (and it was definitely "our" battle).  Take care of yourself sweetie and I will remember your entire family in my prayers (which help more than anything).  Diana
Posts.Title: Worried but dont know for sure...

Posts.Content: On Oct 29, 2011 6:53 PM AlanRinHBG wrote: Hi Diana, Nice to finally see that there really are more survivors on this site who were treated at CTCA. I hope you're doing well. I'm in complete remission with stage IV lung cancer and had no surgery. It's been two years since my last chemo. I continue to take the advice of the naturopath at CTCA and take my daily handful of reccomended supplements. It seems to be working, all scans have shown no changes. Call it "stable", call it "remission", I'm just happy. Stay cool Diana.Hi Alan- I am doing wonderfully and thank you for the kind thoughts. Diana
Posts.Title: Importance of Vit D & Breast C

Posts.Content: On 7/18/2008 Ladyrumpers wrote: I am a 7year survivor, and am due an annual check up very soon.   Apart from my routine mammogram  i have not had any other scans etc., i wonder if your medical people or anyone for that matter thinks i should ask for a scan? Or leave well alone i come from scotland and am on the wonderful national health  i do mean this as my husband and i have had wonderful care and treatment.  Lady rumpers Hi Ladyrumpers At the time I went through treatment I met and became good friends w/ someone who had survived pancreatic cancer for 4 yrs 10 mo.  The last year or so they were only doing blood work for markers and when slightly elevated they did nothing except say come back for next check up.  When he returned his blood markers were greatly elevated so they finally did a scan.  The pancreatic cancer was back and had spread.  He attributed the big jump and spreading on the failure to do a scan.  He immediately went to another treatment facility (which is where I met him and his wife) and they are still treating him a year later.  The pancreatic cancer is no longer cureable - just treatable - but he still feels he would have had a fighting chance if they had done an earlier scan - If it has been years since you have had a scan I would say it is not out of order to ask for one.  It's only my opinion but it is better to be safe than sorry.  Diana
Posts.Title: Should I Leave Well Alone?

Posts.Content: I would like to add that if you find information regarding vitamins, or treatment utilizing vitamins, that would be appropriate to post on the alternative treatment section. It is your spouting off about nonprofit organizations - organizations that are helping so many of us -that I find inappropriate for Cancer Compass. Diana
Posts.Title: Importance of Vit D & Breast C

Posts.Content: On Oct 29, 2011 6:53 PM AlanRinHBG wrote: Hi Diana, Nice to finally see that there really are more survivors on this site who were treated at CTCA. I hope you're doing well. I'm in complete remission with stage IV lung cancer and had no surgery. It's been two years since my last chemo. I continue to take the advice of the naturopath at CTCA and take my daily handful of reccomended supplements. It seems to be working, all scans have shown no changes. Call it "stable", call it "remission", I'm just happy. Stay cool Diana.Alan - I too still rely on the naturopathic to advise me on supplements and take them daily. When I go to CTCA for my checkups, it's as if I am going home. I know if there is ever a reoccurrence, they are up for the fight again! I am four years out of treatment and counting!!! I am happy for you that your scans continue to show no change. Diana
Posts.Title: Importance of Vit D & Breast C

Posts.Content: Andy - I'm sure you mean well but the reason why the moderators keep removing your posts are simply because you are on the wrong site. We (cancer patients, survivors, and caregivers) come here to share first hand information and to support each other. We do not come here to have a young man who has acquired just enough knowledge (both accurate and inaccurate) to make him dangerous give us his opinions on the best treatments or tell us how we get cancer (or prevent it) or how non-profits work. We have been in the trenches having fought cancer or are still fighting it! Your spouting off accusations may be acceptable on some sites but this really isn't the right place for them. Don't be surprised if your post gets deleted again.
Posts.Title: Importance of Vit D & Breast C

Posts.Content: On Oct 29, 2011 3:11 AM andy73 wrote: Expected and appreciate all of your messages. Wouldn't waste time on this computer and site if didn't truly care about people and possibly helping someone gain useful and factual information. That's what we all want, factual and truthful information  Have done the homework, lots of hours. The organizations you mention, specifically and especially SGK, while probably formed with good intentions, are not being truthful and transparent with the public and people who give them millions of their hard earned dollars  Recommend watching 'Healing Cancer from the Inside Out' by Mike Anderson, for a good start on understanding these organizations.  And listening to Mike Adams, who talked just tonight actually, 10/28, and touched on these organizations -  http://www.renegadehealth.com/cancer/blog/ "" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">http://www.renegadehealth.com/cancer/blog/ " target="_blank" rel="nofollow">http://www.renegadehealth.com/cancer/blog/ Also, any legitimate breast cancer foundation truly devoted to eradicating this disease will have studied the research on Vit D and be recommending supplementation or getting enough sun  to ALL women. What does SGK say about Vit D?  mums the word. Shame on them  Andy I am going to try one last time to get through to you. Your type of post may be welcomed on some sites but this is the wrong place for you!!!! Why? You are correct in that we want factual information but not from someone who is not even wet behind the ears and has NO idea what he is talking about! We, the cancer patients and the caregivers come here to gain information from other cancer patients and survivors - people who have been there and done that! When your own life, or the life of someone you love dearly, is on the line, we have done tons and tons of research. The first thing my husband did after my diagnosis was get onto the Internet. The fact that people found our site is proof that they know how to navigate the net. As for nonprofit organizations, I repeat, this is not the forum to address that issue. The majority are wonderful, caring, supportive groups. Believe me - when you have cancer, the first place you turn is generally one of these groups. As for pink ribbons, do you have any idea of how many people you just offended? The pink ribbon is to bring awareness - which it does, When you are battling cancer, you welcome any and all awareness that calls for a cure. You mention, you mentioned what MAY aide in preventing cancer - people on here already have cancer and can't concern themselves with preventing it - especially a pie in the sky unproven way. FYI - everyone has cancer cells in their body!!!! It is when they begin to clump together that the problem arises. The fact that you could make a really dumb statement about men not being able to get breast cancer (even if you did correct yourself) shows just how little you know! I don't doubt you care but people coming to Cancer Compass are looking for info from the real experts - those who have fought it and won OR are still fighting it. The Cancer Treatment Centers of America have created this site for that purpose and to be there for patients and for caregivers to share info and offer support/comfort! It is NOT, I repeat, it is NOT a site to offer your opinion or my opinion! We don't have time to fight political battles. I watched as my first husband wasted down to 79 pounds before God took him home! I could care less what the outside world was doing! I needed a place to cry, to scream, to rant, when it was evident he was losing a hard fought battle against lung cancer. I didn't have Cancer Compass but I didn't have my Cancer Compass back then so I held it inside. I couldn't let Jack stress more - he already felt guilty because he was leaving me! When I fought my own cancer battle 4 years ago, I could care diddly about what the pharmaceutical companies or any other supposed injustice. My focus was on winning the battle! This is Cancer Compass - compass as in showing the way on a journey - a journey through cancer. As with traveling from New York or Florida to California. The only people who can guide you are those who have traveled the route before you. They know the curves and dips in the road. Someone who has just looked at a map cannot know these dangers. The people who are fighting cancer don't need any additional stress - they have their plates full! If you truly truly truly care about them, you would keep your thoughts about political issues to yourself. Can't you tell by the responses that people are trying nicely to educate you rather than the other way around - much like you would a small child who thinks he knows more than his parents. Please, for their sakes, keep your opinions to yourself OR find a site that was established for this purpose because it is not Cancer Compass. Diana
Posts.Title: Importance of Vit D & Breast C

Posts.Content: On Oct 29, 2011 1:39 PM wvleroyhayes wrote: Andy and a few others here are the reason i seldom use Cancer Compass anymoreThe vast majority of us care deeply for everyone on here which is why I am like a mother hen (or a bear protecting her cubs) when someone posts nonsense that I believe will stress cancer patients even more! Andy, do you understand now why you and a few others like you are actually hurting people here? I judge postings by how I felt watching my husband wither away and how I felt while fighting cancer myself. I did not need or want to read (and try to decipher) posts similar to yours.
Posts.Title: Importance of Vit D & Breast C

We shouldn't become so focused on our own beliefs that we lose sight of the fact that members here are dealing with far more serious issues that have nothing to do with our opinions on a subject! Diana

Posts.Content: On Jul 27, 2012 7:19 AM shannylea wrote: Cancer definitely has a smell. I was dignosed with thyroid cancer a few years ago. During the biopsy I was awake and not numbed at all. When they took the cells out of my neck, there was a very distinct smell. It was not a pleasant one. My next biopsy was of a benign lymph node, and, sure enough, no smell. Now, I have more lumps in my neck andmy urine has begun to take on the same smell as those cancer cells. My next biopsies are on August 1st and it will be interesting if it is in fact thyoid cancer back. Also, pets do act different when you have cancer! My dog wouln't stop licking me obsessively.. I didn't notice a smell but I can easily believe that there would be one.  Also, we all have cancer cells in our body - it is ony when they begin to "clump together" when they become a problem.  Hopefully the first person to post pick up on a lone cancer cell.  I totally believe that dogs can pick up on the smell - they are much more sensitive to smells than humans.

Posts.Title: Free Retreats for Breast Cancer Patients/Survivors

Posts.Content: Hi all I don't know if anyone saw the Today show yesterday morning where they gave information on a wonderful program called Casting For Recovery (CFR).  CFR is a national non-profit support and educational program for women who have or have had breat cancer.  It is a weekend retreat of fly fishing.  I know I wondered what one had to do with the other but they said that it provides gentle exercise for joint and soft tissue mobility that is so badly needed for breast cancer patients as well as emotional support.  The lodging, food, and professional instruction are all free.  You can go to castingforrecovery.com or call 1-888-553-3500 for more information.  I am recovering from tonsil cancer so I not eligible.  Diana
Posts.Title: Free Retreats for Breast Cancer Patients/Survivors

Posts.Content: It appears that you are a newcomer to Cancer Compass and do not know the rules.  You are NOT allowed to post any email addresses in your posts.  Also, do you realize that you can be costing someone their life if they listen to you.  This may or may not have worked for your skin cancer - but skin cancer is very different from other types of cance.  I have a friend currently battling breast cancer because they misdiagnosed her and she didn't receive treatment soon enough.  Her cancer is not cureable and she undergoes chemo weekly only to give her a better quality of the life she has left.  If you want to post a legitimate post on the alternative treatment sight, that may be the place to go but do not post this kind of information on other blogs.  People come to Cancer Compass to hear from people who went through similar treatment - you did not experience any other type of cancer than skin.  You give NO information about yourself in your profile so we don't even know if you are a legitimate poster.  I am a cancer survivor who never advises anyone about cancer if they had a different type than I had - head and neck cancer. I have reported your post as abuse because of the email address you provided.  This site is sponsored (aka paid for) by the Cancer Treatment Centers of America who do believe in alternative along with conventional - NOT total alternative.      Diana
Posts.Title: how i got cured from cancer

Posts.Content: On Jun 19, 2014 2:25 AM rosydosy wrote: Has anyone developed a rash on your head during chemo?  I am Stage 4 Met. Breast Cancer and doing Herceptin, Perjeta, and Taxotere.  My hair started coming out so I had a friend shave it.  Then I noticed the bumps. (hurt and itch) I have been using Nioxin and have even put alcohol on them.  My doctor thought it was folliclitis at first, but noticed some on my back so he thinks it is from chemo.  He was hesitant to put me on an antiobiotic and didn't.  Anyone know what to do to get rid of the bumps?? ThanksCancer keys is absolutely correct about the Benadryl for any kind of allergic reaction. I am allergic to the dye used prior to scans and break out all over. I also have difficulty breathing. My oncologist ordered prednisone 50 mg - one tablet 13 hours before, 7 hours before, and 1 hour before a CT scan. Also, I am to take 1 - 50 mg capsule 1 hour before. I had a serious rash around my port area during treatment which turned out to be an infection. My oncologist put me on an antibiotic which cleared it up. .............I don't see it mentioned often but I also have an allergy to latex that I did not have prior to treatment. Any bandaid, tape, or glove that is made of latex will break me out. A small piece of tape on my arm will result in my entire arm breaking out. Diana
